Journal Story: Hiking the Appalachian Trail (AT) has been a long time bucket-list item. The dream was renewed in July 2006 during a family vacation in north GA. Hiking was not on the vacation agenda; however, our final day’s adventure to Amicalola Falls State Park resulted in a family photo at a stone arch. The sign next to the arch stated “Appalachian Trail Approach, Springer Mtn 8.5 miles, Mt Katahdin, Maine 2,185 miles.”   I had not thought of the AT in a very long time. “Oooooo the trail” echoed through my brain as the hiking bug firmly planted its teeth into the mushy content of my skull. Arriving home, I dug out my old 20 year camping/hiking gear, searched the net for an easy trail access points, and planned a weekend getaway. I’ve logged over 500 AT miles since then but the 3-7 day ventures have not curb my appetite to hike the entire trail. My turn has finally come. On April 4 2017, I will set off for what I hope to be a complete north bound journey of the world renowned Appalachian Trail. Oh yeah!

So many options. So many opinions. Ask 10 hikers about gear choices and you’ll get 10 answers. Tent or hammock? Canister or alcohol stove? Wool or synthetic base layers? What about rain gear, hiking poles, or shoes? I’ve come to the conclusion that there is not a perfect gear set-up. Gear choice is what works best for the individual hiker and knowing how to use that gear. Over the last 10 years of section hiking, I’ve used three different tents, two hammocks, three sleeping bag/quilts, four stoves, three packs, and a variety of sleeping pads and clothing options. Each new selection was a bit lighter weight than the previous. All previous gear setups worked well enough. I had likes and dislikes for each. So what shall I do? Use a different hammock, quilt, pack, and stove of course. My choices include: Arc Zip backpack from Zpacks. Sparrow hammock from Dream Hammock. Flight Jacket and Zepplin quilts (both 20 degree down) from Under Ground Quilts. I’m still on the fence about stove options. Base layers will be merino wool. I’ll start the hike with low cut hiking shoes and then switch to trail runners. I lean toward a lightweight setup without getting too crazy about every ounce. While keenly aware of how quickly ounces add to pounds, I’m not interested in cutting my toothbrush or towel in half. I will carry some comfort items, a small pillow, designated sleeping clothes, and a camera. Currently, my base weight is 14 lbs (food and water excluded) & (extra warm clothing is included). I’ll lose about 3 lbs of gear when the weather warms up.

Training for a long distance hike is difficult, especially if you live in flat-land Florida. I have been prepping for this thru hike for nearly a year despite not knowing if it was really going to happen. Truth is, I needed to exercise more anyway. The notion of hiking was pure motivation. Most days, I fast walk a six mile course at a local park. I’ll jog parts of the course for cardio. The mixture of walking and jogging has helped a great deal but long, steep hills are what I really need. The best I can do for hills (without driving an hour) are parking garages and bike path over-passes. They’re not very exciting or picturesque but they provide a leg work-out. Recently, I added a 12 pound day pack to the walk.

I’m excited to receive the commemorative thru-hiker hangtag from the AT Conservatory in the mail today. These yellow tags are sent to hikers that preregister as a thru hiker. I’ll happily carry it all the way to Katahdin, ME.

So much stinkin’ thinkin’. Thinking a lot about the trail. I'm eager to get started. Much of the thinking time is just good entertainment; rehashing gear choices, clothing options, start date, and am I doing enough to get ready - physically. I’m settled on most gear options but still trying to eliminate what is unnecessary. Example, do I really need that pillow, drinking mug, a designated set of sleeping clothes, or camp shoes. They’re nice to have but but add weight and volume to the pack. Cold weather clothing options are the hardest. Thin blooded from 17 years of warm Florida living has me concerned about being cold while on the trail. Heck, I’m reaching for a jacket at 60 degrees. April 4th is my start date but that seems sooooo far away. Do I dare depart late March? I’m walking six miles nearly every day with little jogging mixed in. And finally, I’m back on the diet… I’d like to shed 10 pounds before setting out. Thinking…thinking… so much stinkin’ thinkin’. I wouldn't want it any other way.

Wow! No turning back now. Today, I gave my three weeks’ notice. Very surreal and exciting all at once. I will miss many of my co-workers, especially, those I’ve known and worked with for nearly 17 years.

Arrived Springer Mountain today thanks to expert back-road driving by Liz. Today's plan was to scope out the drive and return Monday for the official start. I was so amped up I started today. Doing so gave Liz a shorter drive home on Monday. I did it for her...yeah, that'sounds the ticket. Weather threaten rain most of the day. There were a few showers and one good down pour. Temps hovered in the mid 60s. Perfect for hiking.
Good day for hiking. No rain. Pushed to Preacher Rock (1/2 mile north of Woody Gap). Sassafras and Justus Mountains were the challenges of the day.

Big thunderstorm last night. The tarp held and I stayed dry. I was worried each time a strong wind gusts came over the ridge. Woke to a beautiful sunrise with low clouds in the valley. Very nice. Today's challenge was Blood mountain. Temps are expected to drop to 45 tonight.
Another great date on the AT. Met hikers from Canada, Wisconsin, Florida, and Australia. Temps were in the 70 this afternoon. Hiked a little beyond Low Gap Shelter.

Due to the threat of severe thunderstorms, I hoped off the trail for the night. I needed a shower anyway. Fortunately, Mind The Gap Ministries was cooking burgers for hikers. Yay, trail magic. They were closing down for the afternoon and offered to take a group of us to Top Of Georgia Hostel. A very nice operation. They took great care of us.

Pushed to Carter Gap Shelter. High Winds and rain is expected tonight and tomorrow. Hiked thru large areas of 2016 burn areas. All the ground leafs and small underbrush burned completely. Many of the trees will likely survive. Highlights include views from Standing Indian moutain. Had more trail magic today. Old Goat and Granny finished cooking the final few hamburgers. I got there just in time. I had two burgers, an orange, carrots, spinach, and an energy drink. Yummy.

The rain was not shy last night or today. Gear was a little damp due to the high winds. I wanted to get as close to Franklin as I could. Constant rain and a stiff cool breeze kept me moving. I really kicked it in gear when the lighting started. Long day but I pushed to Franklin so I could try out. No views today. Staying at the Sapphire Inn. Highlights, climbing a very steep Albert Mountain in a downpour and making it safely to Franklin.

Started the day with pancakes and bacon at the local Baptist Church. They have been serving this hiker breakfast for ten years. Did a quick resupply at the Dollar General than shuttled back the Winding Stair. Today's hike was mostly uphill. Gear is clean an dry. There's no rain in the forecast. Happy to be here.

Thunderstorms in the forecast...again. Started hiking at 8:00. The rain began at 10:00. The trail was more like a stream, very slippery in places. I did not intend to hike another 15 mile day. This section of trail not have many places to camp between shelters so I kept walking. Legs are tired so a zero hiking day is needed. Having a great time inspite of the weather

Hiked a rainy mile into the Natahala Outdoor Center. Enjoyed a hot breakfast (eggs, bacon, and grits) at the local restaurant. Another cold rainy day forecasted so I'm taking a rest day. Called a local shuttle driver (Villa) she gave us a quick tour of the down and dropped three of us off at the hotel. Laundry, shower, and town food.

Enjoyed today's hike. Started at the Nantahala Outdoor Center and hiked thru a variety of trail. Lower elevations showed signs of early spring. Hiked thru a large area of pine forest. Higher elevation had snow on the ground. Tonight's temps are expected to be in the mid 30s...brrrr. I hope to be snug and warm between my 20 degree quilts.

Hiked 18 miles today. What was I thinking? The target stop lacked trees I needed to hang so I kept walking. I also wanted to get into Smoky Mountain National Park while the weather was still favorable. Slept great last night despite the "party" atmosphere at the nearby shelter. Shelter life is a lot like middle school. That's all I'll say about that.

Mostly an uphill climb all the way to the shelter. Legs are feeling worked out. Shelter is crowded. 15 in the shelter, 9 tents and 2 hammocks. Weather is outstanding. Blue skys in the mid 60s. Having a great time. Large areas of the forest floor is carpeted with white wildflowers.

Slow hiking today due to a hitch in my giddy-up. Left quad is a little sore. Had some beautiful views from Rocky Top. Mostly blue skies today in the upper 60s. Good crowd at the shelter tonight. Campfire chat was mostly about getting to Gatlinburg for real food.
Short relaxing hike today. I'm set up to reach Gatlinburg, TN tomorrow. Hiked with a Father/daughter (trail names, U-turn and Colonel) team from Iowa this morning.

Woke early this morning. Was hiking by headlamp in an attempt to catch sunrise at Clingmans Dome. Clingmans is the highest elevation on the AT. Unfortunately, cloud cover blocked the sunrise. Arrived Newfound Gap around 1:30. Enjoyed the view, made a hotel reservation, and hitched a ride to Gatlinburg. Passed on the first ride offer- small car with four young occupants. The second offering was from an elderly couple from Michigan who enjoyed helping hikers. They drove me right to the hotel.

Taking a zero day (no trail miles) in Gatlinburg. Gatlinburg is a tourist mecca. Main street is a mix of a carnival midway and shopping mall food court. It's not as stuck in the 1970s as I feared. There's a modern feel with a twist of nostalgia. People like it...the place is packed.

Caught a very early shuttle out of Gatlinburg. The shuttle is set up for hikers who want to see the sunrise at Clingmans Dome. Several of us exited at Newfound Gap and headed north using our headlamps. Good day of hiking. Trail conditions on the north side of the Park are much improved.
Determined to exit Smoky Mtn National Park today.

A long but good hiking day. Started and ended with a steep ascent but in between fairly easy trail. A bit tired after a few long hiking days. I'll have to cut back in the daily miles. Had trail magic at a road crossing this morning, scrabble eggs, oranges, and doughnuts Yum! Glad to be here.
Had a misstep the other day going downhill. What I thought was an 8 inch drop was closer to a 12 inch drop. The extra 4 inch drop sent a shockwave from my toes to my skull. Ouch!
Hiked to Hot Springs today. The trail goes right down main street. Staying the night in one of the many hostels. Hot shower, town food, and laundry done.

Had a little rain today. Was not bad until the wind kicked up. I thought about staying in Hot Springs another day but the room I was in was not available. Most places are booked due to weather concerns. No rooms in town so to the trail I go. This shelter is on the ridge so with the expected rain a higher winds it may be chilly night in the hammock. P.S. slept great.
Got a late start this morning. Thunderstorms are in the forecast later today. Arrived at the shelter around 3:00. Set up camp and relaxed.
More rain was expected so I got an early start, (hiking by 7am). Only a few light showers. No views today so no pictures. Made it to camp before the real rain came.

The trail was slick from last night's rain. The rainy weather pattern continues. My going in plan was to hike to the next shelter area (11 miles) and call it a day. 11 miles in with no rain, I gambled for another 4 miles to Low Gap camp area. Mistake! Rained like crazy then I missed the camp area. Oops. Not many options before Bald Mtn Shelter so I pressed on. Fortunately, the rain took a break so I enjoyed nice views crossing the grassy bald. Got the tarp and hammock set up before...you guessed it...more rain.

Another early start to play the rain game. Good news, only one 30 minute downpour today. Better news, I was near a shelter so I waited it out under cover. I was thinking about setting camp, but a young hiker, Little Goat, reminded me about tomorrow's 90% rain/thunderstorm forecast and how nice trail food would be. He was right. Thanks Little Goat. Made it to Erwin,TN. Happy, happy.
Zero day in Erwin.

Short hike day. Shuttled back to the trail around noon. Yesterday's rain turned much of the hiking trail into streams. Walked slow to keep my shoes dry. I do not like walking in soggy socks. Arrived at the shelter around 3pm. More rain in the expected so I set camp. Then the party crowd showed up. Very entertaining night. Some can really go at it.

Went long today, 21.9 miles, to create some distance from the party crowd. I also want to get closer to Roan Mountain so I could tackle it good weather. Mostly cloud today. The sun managed to peak thru the clouds once. I'm set to Roan Mtn tomorrow. All is well still having fun.
Hiked Roan Mountain (6000 foot elevation) today in ideal weather. Great to have a day with no forecasted rain. After Roan I hike over the first if several grassy balds. A great day to be out.

Up and over two beautiful grassy balds, Little Hump and Hump Mountain. Nothing little about them. Awesome views. The wind nearly knocked me down twice. Predicted thunderstorms were rolling in as I approached 19E. Do I hunt for a camp site or head to town? Trail magic shows up again. The Doe River Hostel shuttle pulls up and offers a ride. Yay. Shower, laundry, a bed, and town food. Double cheese burger, fries, and a chocolate milk shake. All is well.
Beautiful trail this morning. Hiked in and out of forest and open field. Blue skies all day.

Another grand day on the trail. Did not see many hikers today. Elevation changes were fairly easy.  Hiked to Laurel waterfall then hiked around Watauga Lake.  Part of the trail near the lake was 10 inches under water. I hunted around for an alternative path knowing most hikers were not going to soak their shoes.  It took a few moments but I made it around dry. Found a secluded campsite over looking the lake. Very nice.

Fairly easy trail today.  Elevation changes were were mild compared to previous days.  Most of the day was under tree canopy with the exception of a mile of open field toward days end.  Good crew at the shelter.  Sat around a campfire chatting with several section hikers. Have not seen the party crowd in several days. Winds are expected tonight with a high chance of rain tomorrow.

The foretasted rain was much lighter than feared.  I pushed to Damascus, VA to avoid setting up in the rain. The lure of town food and a much needed shower was a major motivator.  Crossed into VA today. Yay, another state completed.  Most of today's hiking was downhill.  Knees are tired.  Will take a zero day tomorrow.

Zero day in Damascus.  Staying at the Woodchuck hostel.  Choice of accommodations: semi private room (main house), bunk house, tent in the backyard or teepee. yes, there is a  teepee in the backyard.  Nice place.  Several of us attempted to defeat the hostel owner at corn-hole.  We all failed.  Enjoyed townifood and a full days rest.

Departed Woodchuck hostel  around 9 am.  Walked north through town (the trail goes down main street)  to the trail-head.   There I stood for what seemed a very long time debating what to do next.  My hiking mojo was in the tank.  Thoughts of home were on my mind.  What to do?  Today's goal was the second trail shelter, only 12 miles.  I altered the goal to to first shelter, an easy 6 miles.  But my legs remained still.   Maybe another zero day.   No, it's time to visit home.  So with out disappointment I rented a car and drove the FL unsure if I would return to the trail this year.  The 470 miles hiked was a great experience.  Met many terrific people and saw beautiful places.

I've been off the trail for over two weeks.  No regrets about returning home.  Just needed some quality family time.  Several house projects were completed.  I'm well rested and ready to return to the trail.   Waiting for backpack repair pieces from Zpacks.  Had issues with several straps slipping, making the pack uncomfortable.
Great to be back on the trail. Dropped the rental off in Abingdon then shuttled to Damascus.  Picked up the trail where I left off weeks ago. This section parallels the Virginia Creeper trail.

Got an early start thus morning. The threat of rain lingers.  Started with an occasional  light drizzle.  The clouds let loose their payload just before noon.  Arrived at the shelter area early afternoon.  The trees, mostly pine grow close together so it took a while to locate a suitable place for the hammock.  Misty fog all night soaked anything exposed to the air.

Today started with wet gear.  Not sure which is worse, putting on yesterday's wet socks and shoes or a cold wet tee shirt.  Fairly easy hiking through Grayson Highlands.  Views were obscured by the fog but the wild ponies did not disappoint.  found a great hang spot.  Glad to be here.

The sun peaked through the clouds a few times today.  Started today with damp clothes and soggy shoes again, yuck. The best part about soggy shoes is no worries about trail puddles, just plow right through them.  A good day despite the wet trail.

Yay, sunny all day.  Got an early start to reach Mount Rogers visitor center, Marion Va.  Time to resupply, laundry, and shower. Met up with Roaming Gnome, a hiker I met in Damascus in early May. We got off the trail the same time I did. He returns today. We will team up to tackle the AT. After chores, we headed down the trail. Nice to have company.
Beautiful trail today meandering between forest and open field. Enjoyed trail magic (snacks and cold drinks) at the old school house.

Enjoyed a great breakfast at the Inn. Started hiking around 9am. The last four miles was a long uphill climb. Worn me out.  Water sources were far apart. The shelter has a gorgeous view of the valley.

Only 10 miles today. Energy levels were low and the trail was very rocky.  Never found a hiking rhythm. Attempted to catch a ride to a hostel for a hot lunch.  The shuttle was delayed so we wasted a lot of hiking time.  Some days the trail wins the mental battle.
